title-group.article-title: Consumer Benefits versus Product Attributes: An Experimental Test

abstract.p: Product attributes and subjectively assessed benefits are recognized as alternative ways of providing information about product characteristics for use in multiattribute preference models. Product attributes and two levels of benefits are operationalized and evaluated in an experimental study. The accuracy of the resulting preference models in predicting subjectsÂ¹ independently assessed preference orders is the criterion for evaluation. The joint MANOVA results and separate ANOVA results for each model indicate highly significant differences in predictive accuracy. Models using the more highly aggregated form of benefits show the highest predictive accuracy, while models based on attributes achieve the lowest levels of predictive accuracy.
